message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: State of the Art in Software Verification and Witness Validation: SV-COMP 2024
Paper Abstract: Abstract The 13th edition of the Competition on Software Verification (SV-COMP 2024) was the largest competition of its kind so far: A total of 76 tools for verification and witness validation were compared. The competition evaluated 59 verification systems and 17 validation systems from 34 teams from 12 countries. This yields a good overview of the state of the art in tools for software verification. The competition was executed on a benchmark set with 30 300 verification tasks for C programs and 587 . verification tasks for Java programs. The specifications again included reachability, memory safety, overflows, and termination. This year was the second time that the competition had an extra competition track on witness validation. We introduced a new witness format 2.0, and a new scoring schema for the validation track. All meta data about the verification and validation tools are available in the FM-Tools repository.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Web search results for query: "Memory safety"

Links: [{"title":"Memory safety - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Memory_safety"},{"title":"Thread safety - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thread_safety"},{"title":"Drowsy driving - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Drowsy_driving"},{"title":"Nootropic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nootropic"},{"title":"John Levesque - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Levesque"},{"title":"Exception safety - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abrahams_guarantees"},{"title":"Memory protection - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Memory_protection"},{"title":"MemTest86 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Memtest86"}]

Based on the search results, here's what memory safety is:

## Overview

Memory safety is the state of being protected from various software bugs and security vulnerabilities when dealing with memory access, such as buffer overflows and dangling pointers.

## Examples and Language Support

Java is memory-safe because its runtime error detection checks array bounds and pointer dereferences. In contrast, C and C++ allow arbitrary pointer arithmetic with pointers implemented as direct memory addresses with no provision for bounds checking, and thus are potentially memory-unsafe.

## Security Significance

Memory safety is a major security concern. In 2019, a Microsoft security engineer reported that 70% of all security vulnerabilities were caused by memory safety issues. Similarly, in 2020, a team at Google reported that 70% of all "severe security bugs" in Chromium were caused by memory safety problems.

## How It's Achieved

The Rust programming language implements a borrow checker to ensure memory safety, while C and C++ provide no memory safety guarantees. Additionally, garbage collected languages combined with automatic bounds checking on all array accesses and no support for raw pointer arithmetic provide strong memory safety guarantees.

I've completed a web search for "Software verification." Here's a summary of the results:

## Overview

Software verification is a discipline of software engineering, programming languages, and theory of computation whose goal is to assure that software satisfies the expected requirements.

## Key Approaches

**Static vs. Dynamic Verification:**
- Static verification is the process of checking that software meets requirements by inspecting the code before it runs.
- Dynamic verification is performed during the execution of software, and dynamically checks its behavior; it is commonly known as the Test phase.

## Verification vs. Validation

Software verification asks the question, "Are we building the product right?"; that is, does the software conform to its specifications? Software validation asks the question, "Are we building the right product?"; that is, does the software do what the user really requires?

## Formal Verification

Formal verification is the use of software tools to prove properties of a formal specification, or to prove that a formal model of a system implementation satisfies its specification.(no content)Prominent examples of verified software systems include the CompCert verified C compiler and the seL4 high-assurance operating system kernel.

The search results provide comprehensive information on different verification methodologies, their applications, and how they differ from validation processes.

Web search results for query: "Formal verification"

Links: [{"title":"Formal verification - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Formal_verification"},{"title":"ISP Formal Verification Tool - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISP_Formal_Verification_Tool"},{"title":"Formal methods - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Formal_methods"},{"title":"Verification condition generator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Verification_condition_generator"},{"title":"High-level verification - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/High-level_verification"},{"title":"Verification and validation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Verification_and_validation"},{"title":"Compiler correctness - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Compiler_correctness"},{"title":"Murφ - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mur%CF%86"},{"title":"Joseph Sifakis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/J._Sifakis"},{"title":"IBM Israel - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IBM_Haifa_Labs"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about formal verification:

## Definition

In the context of hardware and software systems, formal verification is the act of proving or disproving the correctness of a system with respect to a certain formal specification or property, using formal methods of mathematics.

## Key Approaches

Formal verification employs several main techniques:

1. **Model Checking**: Model checking involves a systematic and exhaustive exploration of the mathematical model, with exploration possible for finite models as well as some infinite models, usually consisting of exploring all states and transitions by using smart and domain-specific abstraction techniques.

2. **Deductive Verification**: This consists of generating from the system and its specifications a collection of mathematical proof obligations and discharging these obligations using either proof assistants or automatic theorem provers, including satisfiability modulo theories (SMT) solvers.

3. **Other Techniques**: Subareas of formal verification include deductive verification, abstract interpretation, automated theorem proving, type systems, and lightweight formal methods.

## Mathematical Models

Examples of mathematical objects used to model systems are: finite-state machines, labelled transition systems, Horn clauses, Petri nets, vector addition systems, timed automata, hybrid automata, process algebra, and formal semantics of programming languages.

## Industrial Application

Formal verification is used by most or all leading hardware companies, but its use in the software industry is still limited. This could be attributed to the greater need in the hardware industry, where errors have greater commercial significance.

Web search results for query: "Buffer overflow"

Links: [{"title":"Buffer overflow - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buffer_overflow"},{"title":"Stack buffer overflow - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stack_buffer_overflow"},{"title":"Buffer overflow protection - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buffer_overflow_protection"},{"title":"Wikipedia:Peer review/Buffer overflow/archive1 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Peer_review/Buffer_overflow/archive1"},{"title":"Heap overflow - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heap_overflow"},{"title":"Video buffering verifier - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Video_buffering_verifier"},{"title":"Talk:Heap overflow - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Heap_overflow"},{"title":"Segmentation fault - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Segmentation_fault"},{"title":"Code Red (computer worm) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Code_Red_(computer_worm)"},{"title":"Traffic shaping - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Overflow_condition"}]

## Buffer Overflow

A buffer overflow is an anomaly whereby a program writes data to a buffer beyond the buffer's allocated memory, overwriting adjacent memory locations.

### How It Works

A buffer overflow occurs when data written to a buffer corrupts data values in memory addresses adjacent to the destination buffer due to insufficient bounds checking, which can happen when copying data from one buffer to another without first checking that the data fits within the destination buffer.

### Security Implications

By sending in data designed to cause a buffer overflow, it is possible to write into areas known to hold executable code and replace it with malicious code, or to selectively overwrite data pertaining to the program's state, causing unintended behavior.(no content)Buffers are widespread in operating system code, so it is possible to make attacks that perform privilege escalation and gain unlimited access to the computer's resources.

### Types of Buffer Overflows

There are two main types:
- **Stack Buffer Overflow**: A stack buffer overflow occurs when a program writes to a memory address on the program's call stack outside of the intended data structure, which is usually a fixed-length buffer.
- **Heap Overflow**: A heap overflow is a type of buffer overflow that occurs in the heap data area.

### Protection Measures

Modern operating systems use a variety of techniques to combat malicious buffer overflows, notably by randomizing the layout of memory, or deliberately leaving space between buffers and looking for actions that write into those areas ("canaries").

Based on the search results, here's an overview of reachability analysis:

## Definition

Reachability analysis is a solution to the reachability problem in the particular context of distributed systems, used to determine which global states can be reached by a distributed system which consists of a certain number of local entities that communicated by the exchange of messages.

## Purpose and Output

The result of reachability analysis is a global state transition graph (also called reachability graph) which shows all global states of the distributed system that are reachable from the initial global state, and all possible sequences of send, consume and service interactions performed by the local entities.(no content)The transition graph can be used for checking general design flaws of the protocol, but also for verifying that the sequences of service interactions by the entities correspond to the requirements given by the global service specification of the system.

## Challenges

In many cases this transition graph is unbounded and can not be explored completely. Additionally, a practical issue of reachability analysis is the so-called "state space explosion" — if the two entities of a protocol have 100 states each, and the medium may include 10 types of messages, up to two in each direction, then the number of global states in the reachability graph is bound by the number 100 x 100 x (10 x 10) x (10 x 10) which is 100 million.

## Related Applications

Reachability analysis has applications across multiple domains, including reachability problems in infinite state systems, rewriting systems, dynamical and hybrid systems; reachability problems in logic and verification; reachability analysis in different computational models, counter timed/cellular/communicating automata; and Petri nets.

Web search results for query: "Program termination"

Links: [{"title":"Termination analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Termination_analysis"},{"title":"exit (system call) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exit_(system_call)"},{"title":"Size-change termination principle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Size-change_termination_principle"},{"title":"Exit status - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exit_status"},{"title":"Terminate-and-stay-resident program - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Terminate-and-stay-resident_program"},{"title":"Indian termination policy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_termination_policy"},{"title":"Graceful exit - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graceful_exit"},{"title":"Program Segment Prefix - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Program_Segment_Prefix"},{"title":"Total functional programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Total_functional_programming"},{"title":"COM file - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COM_file"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about program termination:

## Overview

On many computer operating systems, a computer process terminates its execution by making an exit system call.(no content)More generally, an exit in a multithreading environment means that a thread of execution has stopped running.

## Exit Status

In computing, the exit status (also exit code or exit value) of a terminated process is an integer number that is made available to its parent process (or caller).(no content)Systems returning an integer value commonly use a zero value to indicate successful execution and non-zero values to indicate error conditions.

## Resource Management

The exit operation typically performs cleanup operations within the process space before returning control back to the operating system. Some systems and programming languages allow user subroutines to be registered so that they are invoked at program termination before the process actually terminates.

## Graceful Exit

A graceful exit (or graceful handling) is a simple programming idiom wherein a program detects a serious error condition and "exits gracefully" in a controlled manner as a result.(no content)The code associated with a graceful exit may also take additional steps, such as closing files, to ensure that the program leaves data in a consistent, recoverable state.

## Termination Analysis

A termination proof is a type of mathematical proof that plays a critical role in formal verification because total correctness of an algorithm depends on termination.(no content)The theoretical reason for the difficulty in determining termination is the undecidability of the halting problem: there cannot exist some algorithm which determines whether any given program stops after finitely many computation steps.

Web search results for query: "Model checking"

Links: [{"title":"Model checking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Model_checking"},{"title":"Abstract model checking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abstract_model_checking"},{"title":"List of model checking tools - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_model_checking_tools"},{"title":"Clock (model checking) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clock_(model_checking)"},{"title":"Region (model checking) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Region_(model_checking)"},{"title":"Kripke structure (model checking) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kripke_structure_(model_checking)"},{"title":"Category:Model checking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Model_checking"},{"title":"Principles of Model Checking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Principles_of_Model_Checking"},{"title":"BLAST model checker - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BLAST_model_checker"},{"title":"TAPAs model checker - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TAPAs_model_checker"}]

## Model Checking

Model checking is a method for checking whether a finite-state model of a system meets a given specification (also known as correctness).(no content)It is typically associated with hardware or software systems, where the specification contains liveness requirements (such as avoidance of livelock) as well as safety requirements (such as avoidance of states representing a system crash).

### Key Concepts

To solve this problem algorithmically, both the model of the system and its specification are formulated in some precise mathematical language, and the problem is formulated as a task in logic to check whether a structure satisfies a given logical formula.(no content)An important class of model-checking methods has been developed for checking models of hardware and software designs where the specification is given by a temporal logic formula.

### Applications and Challenges

Model checking is most often applied to hardware designs.(no content)Model-checking tools face a combinatorial blow up of the state-space, commonly known as the state explosion problem, that must be addressed to solve most real-world problems.

### Historical Development

Model checking began with the pioneering work of E. M. Clarke, E. A. Emerson, J. P. Queille, and J. Sifakis. Clarke, Emerson, and Sifakis shared the 2007 Turing Award for their seminal work founding and developing the field of model checking.

Links: [{"title":"List of datasets for machine-learning research - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_datasets_for_machine-learning_research"},{"title":"Fashion-MNIST - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fashion-MNIST"},{"title":"Benchmark (computing) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benchmark_(computing)"},{"title":"List of benchmarking methods and software tools - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_benchmarking_methods_and_software_tools"},{"title":"Benchmarking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benchmarking"},{"title":"HammerDB - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HammerDB"},{"title":"List of data science software - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_data_science_software"},{"title":"NBench - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NBench"},{"title":"Credit Benchmark - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Credit_Benchmark"},{"title":"Category:Benchmarks (computing) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Benchmarks_(computing)"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about benchmark dataset software:

## Overview

In computing, a benchmark is the result of running a computer program, or a set of programs, in order to assess the relative performance of an object, by running a number of standard tests and trials against it.(no content)While benchmarking is usually associated with assessing performance characteristics of computer hardware, software benchmarks are also run against compilers or database management systems (DBMS).

## Benchmark Datasets for Machine Learning

Several platforms provide benchmark datasets for machine learning research:

- **OpenML**: A web platform with Python, R, Java, and other APIs for downloading hundreds of machine learning datasets, evaluating algorithms on datasets, and benchmarking algorithm performance against dozens of other algorithms.

- **PMLB**: A large, curated repository of benchmark datasets for evaluating supervised machine learning algorithms that provides classification and regression datasets in a standardized format accessible through a Python API.

- **Metatext NLP**: A web repository maintained by community, containing nearly 1000 benchmark datasets with many tasks from classification to QA, and various languages from English, Portuguese to Arabic.

## Notable Benchmark Examples

Fashion-MNIST is a large, freely available dataset of fashion images commonly used for training and testing machine learning systems and serves as a replacement for the original MNIST database for benchmarking machine learning algorithms.

## Benchmarking Software Features

Features of benchmarking software may include recording/exporting the course of performance to a spreadsheet file, visualization such as drawing line graphs or color-coded tiles, and pausing the process to be able to resume without having to start over.

Web search results for query: "Static program analysis"

Links: [{"title":"Static program analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Static_program_analysis"},{"title":"Category:Static program analysis tools - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Static_program_analysis_tools"},{"title":"Program analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Program_analysis"},{"title":"Category:Static program analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Static_program_analysis"},{"title":"Shape analysis (program analysis) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shape_analysis_(program_analysis)"},{"title":"List of tools for static code analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_tools_for_static_code_analysis"},{"title":"Symbolic execution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symbolic_execution"},{"title":"Cppcheck - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cppcheck"}]

Here's a comprehensive overview of static program analysis based on the search results:

## Definition

Static program analysis (also known as static analysis or static simulation) is the analysis of computer programs performed without executing them, in contrast with dynamic program analysis, which is performed on programs during their execution.

## Key Characteristics

The sophistication of the analysis performed by tools varies from those that only consider the behaviour of individual statements and declarations, to those that include the complete source code of a program in their analysis.

## Applications

The uses of the information obtained from the analysis vary from highlighting possible coding errors (e.g., the lint tool) to formal methods that mathematically prove properties about a given program. A growing commercial use of static analysis is in the verification of properties of software used in safety-critical computer systems and locating potentially vulnerable code.

Static analysis can discover vulnerabilities during the development phase of the program. These vulnerabilities are easier to correct than the ones found during the testing phase since static analysis leads to the root of the vulnerability.

## Common Techniques

Key techniques used in static program analysis include:

- Abstract interpretation, which models the effect that every statement has on the state of an abstract machine. The abstract system is made simpler to analyze, at the expense of incompleteness, though if properly done, abstract interpretation is sound.

- Data-flow analysis, a lattice-based technique for gathering information about the possible set of values, and Hoare logic, a formal system with a set of logical rules for reasoning rigorously about the correctness of computer programs.

- Data-flow analysis gathers information about the values at each point of the program. One well-known example is taint checking, which considers variables containing user-supplied data as "tainted," preventing their use until sanitized, often used to prevent SQL injection attacks.

## Security Applications

In the application security industry the name static application security testing (SAST) is also used. SAST is an important part of Security Development Lifecycles (SDLs) such as the SDL defined by Microsoft and a common practice in software companies.

message_text:
Excellent! I've successfully completed the analysis of the SV-COMP 2024 paper. Here's a summary of what was done:

## Analysis Complete ✅

**Paper Classification:** `contribution`

The paper was classified as a "contribution" because it:
- Introduces a new witness format 2.0
- Proposes a new scoring schema for the validation track
- Presents the largest competition of its kind with novel evaluation methodology

**Extracted Triples (10 entities):**

The analysis identified 10 key entities with their relationships:

1. **Software verification** (uses, task) - Core task evaluated
2. **Formal verification** (uses, method) - Mathematical foundation
3. **Model checking** (uses, method) - Key verification technique
4. **Static program analysis** (uses, method) - Program analysis approach
5. **Reachability analysis** (uses, task) - First verification property
6. **Memory safety** (uses, task) - Second verification property
7. **Buffer overflow** (uses, task) - Third verification property (overflows)
8. **Termination analysis** (uses, method) - Fourth verification property
9. **Benchmark** (proposes, data) - Novel benchmark set with 30,300 C and 587 Java tasks
10. **Software testing** (uses, method) - Related to witness validation

**Validation Result:** ✅ All checks passed
- Verified all Wikipedia URLs
- Confirmed paper_type is set
- Confirmed at least 1 "uses" relation (required for all papers)
- Confirmed at least 1 "proposes" relation (required for contribution papers)

Sources:
- [Software verification](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_verification)
- [Formal verification](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Formal_verification)
- [Model checking](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Model_checking)
- [Static program analysis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Static_program_analysis)
- [Reachability analysis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reachability_analysis)
